chapter.title: openCDMS Web
chapter.para: This chapter describes how to use the openCDMS Web Interface, which allows access to parts of the openCDMS system via a web browser.

section.title: Accessing openCDMS Web
section.para: The openCDMS Web application can be accessed using a web browser - the URL you need to enter depends upon which system you are using:
Enter your openCDMS username and password that you would normally use to log into Collect and click the 'Login' button. If you don’t have a username and password please contact openCDMS Support.

section.title: Data Export
section.para: Data entered into a study held by openCDMS can be exported to a zip file containing data and metadata files. This can then be used by tools such as a spreadsheet or statistical package for examination and analysis.
Exports are requested by using openCDMS Web. All export requests are processed overnight and an email is sent out when the export is ready for download.

section.title: Requesting an export
section.para: To request an export, select the relevant project:
Select the centres and sites to be included
Select the export format
Select the documents to be exported
Finally, select any additional parameters, such as the document statuses to be included in the export.
You will receive a confirmation screen to show that a data export request has been successful.

section.title: Viewing requests and downloading exports
section.para: You can view the status of an export at any time, by selecting the link on the main data export page. This page shows a complete history of all export requests that you have made. Any requests still pending can be cancelled if desired.

Requests that have been completed will have a link to download the data as a zip file. Presently, completed exports are not removed from the server so can be downloaded at any point and as many times as required.
MD5 and SHA1 hashes are available to check the validity of the export once it has been downloaded.

section.title: Reporting
section.para: The reports section allows you to generate three different types of reports in real time. The report types are:

listitem.para: Individual Record Reports - These reports display the answers to a particular document for one participant.
Trends Reports - Trends reports summarise replies across multiple participants for a particular document.

Management Reports - Provides information about the overall project. Can aid project management by providing auditing and monitoring information. The reports available include recruitment, record status and UKCRN reports.

section.para: Reports can be generated in several different formats, these are:

listitem.para: PDF – Portable document format. This will produce a graphical display of the report data and can be viewed using a program such as Adobe viewer.
XLS – MS Excel format; a spreadsheet showing the raw data.
CSV – Comma separated values; a plain text file, showing the raw data. Can be imported into statistical programs, including spreadsheet programs like MS Excel.

section.title: Individual Record Reports
section.para: Record reports display the replies to a document for a particular participant in a tabular or graphical format. These reports are also available in Collect, in PDF format, under the ‘Generate Report’ option in the Database menu.
Select ‘Individual Record’ from the Reports submenu on the left-hand side of the screen. You will then be taken through a wizard-like form to generate the report.
To start, select the project and click ‘continue’.
Then select the name of the report to be generated, these correspond with documents in the study.
Next, select the participant identifier for the participant whose data you wish to view.
Select the format of the report. If you want to view the raw data in a spreadsheet program then select XLS or CSV format. Otherwise, select PDF for a graphical view.

Finally, review the options you’ve chosen and click on ‘Generate Report’. If you want to change any selection at any point, simply click on the ‘back’ button. When the report is complete a dialog box will prompt you to open the document in an appropriate program or save it to disk.

section.title: View Trends
section.para: Trends reports are used to display trends in the data from a particular document across many participants. The data can be summarised as an average (with a choice of mean or median) or displaying the minimum or maximum values.
After clicking on the ‘Show Trends’ option in the reports submenu, select a study:
Then select a report:
The remaining form options required for generating a report are shown in the screenshots below.

First, select the centres and sites that should be included in the report. Then the start and end dates, which allow you to choose the time period covered by the report (the dates are based on when the participant’s details were first saved to the database).

The summary type allows you to specify how the data is summarised and can include the options: mean, median, low, high. The option to show totals will display the number of participants included in the report for each month. Then select the format the report is displayed in.

Finally, click ‘continue’. You will be given the opportunity to review your choices before clicking on ‘Generate Report’. The report may take a few minutes to be created depending on the number of centres and participants included; when it’s done a dialog box will then prompt you to open the document in an appropriate program or save it to disk.

section.title: Generating a report
section.para: Management reports allow you to monitor the progress of a study and view data for auditing. From the reports submenu select ‘Project Management’. You will then be prompted to select a project:
Then select a report:

The form wizard will then take you through the options required for the report selected. These options are similar to the ones required to generate record or trends reports, as shown in the previous sections. Finally, you will be prompted to select a format for the report (with a choice of PDF, XLS or CSV) and then asked to review your selections before the report is generated.

section.title: UKCRN Reports
section.para: The openCDMS Web application can be used to create reports suitable for submission to the UKCRN, in accordance with the UKCRN’s standard accrual data format. These reports are required periodically by the UKCRN for any project included in the UKCRN portfolio.

To generate a UKCRN report, follow the steps listed in the previous section to generate a management report and select the report named ‘UKCRN report’ for the appropriate project. You will be prompted to enter the start and end dates for the report, which are normally specified by the UKCRN and the format, which must be CSV, as required by the UKCRN.

section.title: Other Management Reports
section.para: This section outlines the purposes of other management reports commonly used in projects. Please note that not all reports are available for all projects.

listitem.para: Recruitment Progress Report. This report shows the recruitment numbers per month, for the specified centres in a project. An optional target can be entered for each month to be displayed alongside the recruitment figure. The recruitment number for any given month is based on the date that a participant’s details were first committed to the database.

CI, PI and CPM Reports. These reports display the number of participants entered into a study and the number of participants currently in each particular participant status (such as referred, consented, baseline completed, etc), often broken down by centre.

Record Status Report. The record status report shows the overall status of each participant in the selected centres and the progress of their record through each study stage, i.e it states whether a study stage has been completed, started but not complete or not started. It is best viewed in XLS or CSV format.
Document Status Report. The document status report shows the current status of all documents for each participant in the selected centres. It is best viewed in XLS or CSV format.

Document Collection Date Report. This report displays the date certain documents were collected for the participants in the selected centres and includes the date of first contact with the participant. The documents included in this report are the ones for which the date of collection is explicitly specified and so the date used is the date the data was collected (which may differ from the date it was entered onto the system). It is best viewed in XLS or CSV format.

Missing Codes Usage Report. This report is useful for monitoring the usage of missing codes as part of a data quality audit. It shows the occurrences of missing codes in documents, and further breaks this down by question and participant. This can be useful to ensure certain documents or questions are not simply being skipped; the participant view allows you to see what participants are affected and who was responsible for data entry. This report is best viewed in XLS format.

Basic Statistics Report. This report displays statistics on certain entries on the selected document across all participants in the chosen centres. It can display the mean, mode, median, minimum or maximum values for each of the entries specified.

Receiving Treatment Report. This report is specific to trials using the openCDMS randomisation application and shows a list of participants, their NHS numbers and randomisation details, grouped by treatment type. This can show the project as a whole or broken down by centre. This report is best viewed in XLS format.

section.title: Participant Register
section.para: The Participant Register allows the user to perform the following tasks:

listitem.para: To find an identifier for a participant using some of their personal details.
To find the personal details for a participant given their participant identifier.
To update the personal details for a participant.
To find a treatment arm for a participant using some of their personal details.
To find a treatment arm for a participant using their participant identifier.
To retrieve a list of all participants and their assigned randomised treatment arms (emergency break-in)

section.para: The tasks available to users will depend on their role within the system e.g. a clinical research officer will not be able to retrieve a list of all participants and their assigned treatment arms.

section.title: Selecting a Study and Centre
section.para: Before you can begin submitting queries to the Participant Register, you must choose a study and centre. Select a study and centre from the drop-down box and click 'Activate'.

figure.title: Participant Register - Select study and centre

section.para: After activating a study and centre, the user bar (underneath the page heading) will indicate your username, study, centre and roles within the currently selected study.

section.title: Participant Identifier by Details
section.para: If you know some personal details about a participant and wish to find their participant identifier, choose the 'Participant Identifier by details' link on the navigation bar at the left-hand side of the screen. Fill in as many details as you can about the participant and click the ‘Search’ button at the bottom of the screen. If a match is found with the details you entered, the participant identifier of this participant will be returned. If no match is found, you will be informed and may run another search.

section.title: Details by Participant Identifier
section.para: If you wish to find the personal details of a participant and know their participant identifier, choose the ‘Details by participant identifier’ link on the navigation bar. Enter the participant identifier in the box provided and choose ‘Search’.
If your search is successful, the results of your search will be displayed as shown in the screenshot below.

figure.title: Participant Register - Details and Participant Identifier

section.para: If your search does not find a unique match with the participant identifier you entered, you will be able to run another search.

section.title: Updating the Personal Details for a Participant
section.para: Both methods detailed above to search for a participant can be used for editing their details, simply click on the ‘Edit’ button instead of ‘Search’.

If a match is found with the participant identifier or details that you entered, you will be taken to the ‘Update personal details’ form, where you can make changes and submit them using the “Update details” button. Note: the maximum number of characters that may be entered to the ‘Risk Issues’ textbox is 4096.

section.title: Treatment Arm by Participant Identifier
section.para: If you know the participant identifier of a participant and wish to find the randomised treatment arm to which they have been assigned, click the 'Treatment arm by number' link on the navigation bar on the left-hand side of the screen. This will present a screen in which you can enter the participant identifier of the participant.

figure.title: Participant Register - Find treatment arm by participant identifier

section.para: Enter the participant identifier and click the 'Search' button. This will then return the result of your search. If no matching study number was found a message will be displayed and you will be able to enter an alternative participant identifier to check.

section.title: Treatment arm by details
section.para: If you know some personal details about a participant and wish to find the randomised treatment arm to which they have been assigned, click the 'Treatment arm by details" link on the navigation bar on the left-hand side of the screen. Fill in as many details as you know about the participant and click the 'Find treatment arm' button (either at the top or bottom of the screen).

figure.title: Participant Register - Find treatment arm by details

section.para: A search will be run to match the details you entered with a participant and the result will be returned. The participant identifier and treatment arm will be displayed in the same way as for Treatment Arm By Participant Identifier. If a unique match is not found, you will be informed and you may enter new details to run another search.

section.title: Emergency Break-in
section.para: The emergency break-in option allows you to see all the treatments assigned to the participants in your project. A list of all participant identifiers and treatments are displayed.

section.title: Treatment arm statistics
section.para: The treatment arm statistics display the real time allocation statistics per strata.

section.title: Change Password
section.para: To change your password via the openCDMS Web Application, select the ‘Change Password’ option from the menu on the left-hand side of the screen. You will be asked to enter your current password and your new password. Your new password must be entered twice. Passwords must be at least six characters in length, and an indication of how secure the new password is will be given (for tips on choosing a secure password see ). When you have entered your current and new passwords, click the ‘Change Password’ button to change your password. You will be notified of the success or failure of this operation. If the operation is successful, your password will now have changed for both the openCDMS Web Application and for Collect.

section.title: Logging Off
section.para: When you are finished using the Participant Register Web Application, you must click ‘Logout’ from the navigation bar on the left-hand side of the screen and fully exit your web browser.

section.title: Problem Reporting
section.para: Although the system has been through extensive testing, no system is ever completely free of problems. Please report problems as you find them. Types of problems that you should report are:

listitem.para: System crashes
Error messages
Inability to do something
Not working as it used to
Not working as you expect
Not working as you would like

section.para: Please provide as much information as you can

listitem.para: What were you doing when it happened
Detail description of the steps that led up to the problem
Is it repeatable, if so how?
What happened?
Details of error messages (if present)

section.para: Bugs can be reported by contactingopenCDMS Support.
When the system crashes, you will see an error message, which will look something like this:
Please email the error message in full to openCDMS Support.
